dt: {bc}of or relating to the earliest age or period {bc}{sx|primeval||}
{bc}closely approximating an early ancestral type {bc}little evolved
{bc}belonging to or characteristic of an early stage of development {bc}{sx|crude||}, {sx|rudimentary||}
{bc}of, relating to, or constituting the assumed parent speech of related languages
{bc}of, relating to, or produced by a people or culture that is nonindustrial and often nonliterate and tribal

et: Middle English {it}prymytyff, primitive{/it} "early (of the Christian church), non-corporeal (of the cause of a disease)," borrowed from Middle French & Medieval Latin; Middle French {it}primitif{/it} "original, primary (of a cause)," borrowed from Medieval Latin {it}prīmitīvus{/it} "belonging to the earliest time or state, original," going back to Latin, "early, first-formed," from {it}prīmitus{/it} "at first, for the first time, originally" (from {it}prīmus{/it} "first, foremost, earliest" + {it}-itus,{/it} adverbial suffix of origin) + {it}-īvus{/it} {et_link|-ive|-ive} {ma}{mat|prime:2|}{/ma}
shortdef: assumed as a basis; especially : axiomatic
of or relating to the earliest age or period : primeval
